ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to read and write in the script, some speaking
Learned the hindi alphabet and basic conversational phrases
Was frustrated with the amount of work, but was so pleasantly surprised by how much I knew when I left the course

I gained a deeper appreciation for the Hindi Language. I also learnt how to read and write Devanagari script and formulate basic sentences and commands in Hindi. I also learnt a fair amount about Indian culture.

This was a really nice introduction to Hindi. I feel more comfortable listening to songs or watching Bollywood movies and though I don't understand much yet, after only level 1, I feel a strong foundation building in the language. I will say that this language is not the one at Yale you want to take if you want to get very good at a language very fast. You certainly learn Hindi, especially if you put in the effort instead of just scraping by, but this is a pretty chill class.
Basic Hindi vocabulary and grammar concepts.

I gained a very solid elementary level of Hindi by taking this course. I can now recognize letters and sound out words that I see in the real world, and also understand some basic dialogue in movies and conversation. I feel most proficient in speaking and writing, and though it takes some time the content is definitely there.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths- profs and tf were very nice and understanding. had a lot of nontraditional content (poems, movies, etc.) that facilitated learning in a more real-worldly applicable environment. also peers were fun to engage with and small class size was nice
weaknesses- very very unstructured, hard to follow lectures. definitely needs more time to go over the script, as if you dont understand that it makes the rest of the class hard. make sure to read the book in advance and get tutoring. also it takes a lot of time bc theres a discussion section in addition to class every day.

Strengths: Very kind professors that make the class engaging
Weaknesses: Lacked structure, felt a bit all over the place

The professors are wonderful! They really care for the growth of their students. It is really such a fun and engaging class to learn a language in. The only main weakness of the course is that it can be disorganized at times.

I did sometimes think this class had a bit too much busy work focusing on less helpful things when more review of concepts and in-class conversational practice would be helpful. With weekly quizzes, Thursday nights and Friday mornings often felt like cramming/catch-up time rather than the learning seeming distributed throughout the week.

Strengths: Teachers are incredibly kind.
Weakness: I feel their explanations of concepts could be better. Class doesn't feel clearly organized every day, so there is more need to rely on the textbook.
I think we should use the vocabulary provided in the book for the weekly vocab quizzes instead of completely separate vocab lists.

The strengths of the course are the kind instructors, the awesome classmates, and the fact that it meets everyday. These things really make the course.

I'd say the biggest weakness of the course is the lack of structure. For the first half of the semester it was very difficult to understand what the main objectives were for class each day and each week. Both Swapna Ji and Savita Ji have a habit of just writing things on the board and teaching the class in a sort of stream of conscious manner, and that is not really helpful when you're trying to get a grasp on a new language. I t would be great if they could better place each assignment, homework, and quiz in context, that way we can really build up an effective toolkit and play a little more of an active role in the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would recommend if you need an easy language credit. otherwise, if you want to learn just for fun i guess u could but it might be hard to pick up enough
I would recommend it if you truly want to learn Hindi. It's graded very leniently, so that's a bonus.
Yes! This is a great language course! The workload is very bearable and the professors and other classmates all make learning the language very fun!

If a student has an interest in Hindi, or Indian culture, or wants to fulfill the distributional requirement with an interesting and useful language, I would recommend this class. Most people in class had some kind of south asian heritage, but there were a few students taking it purely out of interest unrelated to their background. The class vibes are great, it is really fun, and the Hindi department is very understanding and nurturing.
I'm not sure. The teaching can be difficult to follow at times because there seems to be less coordination between the two teachers than there could be.
I would recommend this course, but only if you are going to really take ownership of your learning. As kind as the professors are, it is very very easy to slip through the cracks in this class.
